 Are you near Indonesia? I guess I could go buy someone from Canada or Mexico but I couldn't purchase anyone from Bolivia (or any other nation.)
 
My uncle, a farmer, blatantly violates Leviticus 19:19 by planting two different crops in the same field, as does his wife by wearing garments made of two different kinds of thread (cotton/polyester blend). I have also heard him curse and blaspheme. Is it really necessary that we go to all the trouble of getting the whole town together to stone them? (Leviticus 24:10-16). Couldn't I just smite them?

 You could, but then you'd be breaking the comandment to Not Kill.

I'm saying I don't think many Christian groups, if any at all, let adultery off "scott free." The ones I've been around (evangelical ones, I might add) give MORE attention to condemning adultery than they do homosexuality. What I meant by 'media' is that the press doesn't report it when churches or religious leaders speak out against adultery much, but they DO report the few times churches speak out against homosexuality. And that gives a skewered picture that allows people like OccamRazor to think that condemnation of homosexuality is more prevalent than that of adultery. But that's rarely, if ever, the case.

 Well . . . that argument could be made to say "the commandment "Thou shalt not commit adultery" should be ignored, or the one that says "Thou shalt not murder", just because its hypocritical to hold to THOSE commandments and not, say, touching a woman on her period.
 
 There is a reason for the discrepancy between some commands and others--it's a matter of which ones are moral commands and which ones are ceremonial. The ones that are ceremonial are generally not considered important to follow any more. Commandments against homosexual relations are definitely issues pertaining to sex, and therefore are part of the moral code. 
 
 But perhaps more importantly (for Christians, anyway) are the admonitions against homosexual relations in the New Testament. The Apostle Paul may not have a problem with eating food sacrificed to idols, but he definitely warns against homosexual activities.

 That is a fair point, I was not specific about if I was refering to media representation or teaching within a group, although the former was my motivator to pose the question. However, now you have mentioned the latter I have more to add on that issue as well.
 
 On media representation there is a subtle distinction to be drawn on general teachings available in the public domain (the example of Roman Catholicsm is a good one) and statements that are pointedly made against gays. There are various shades of this:
 
 Legal
 
 Behind the curtains
 
 Pretty extreme (Note that for Robertson while adultery will stp you getting into heaven, the "spread of homsexuality" is the begining of the end of civilisation as we know it. Equal condemnation of sin? I don't think so matey!)
 
 Really extreme.
 
 You see there can be teachings and then there can be active attempts to attack, discriminate against and alienate gay people/homosexuality in general. I find it hard to accept there is any religious justification for this sort of activity. The motivator goes beyond the fight against sin so we have to look for other reasons why, and these seem to be personal dislike, prejudice and bigotry.

But it also condemns sooo many other things, like women on their period, mixed cloth etc etc. WHY do people not equally speak out against this? Unless of course they are just using religion to give weight to their own petty prejudices...

 What were you talking about? I am confused on the woman and her period thing.

Ok, it all stems (like so many dubious things in the Bible) from Leviticus:
 
 
15:19 And if a woman have an issue, and her issue in her flesh be blood, she shall be put apart seven days: and whosoever toucheth her shall be unclean until the even. 
 15:20 And every thing that she lieth upon in her separation shall be unclean: every thing also that she sitteth upon shall be unclean. 
 15:21 And whosoever toucheth her bed shall wash his clothes, and bathe himself in water, and be unclean until the even. 
 15:22 And whosoever toucheth any thing that she sat upon shall wash his clothes, and bathe himself in water, and be unclean until the even. 
 15:23 And if it be on her bed, or on any thing whereon she sitteth, when he toucheth it, he shall be unclean until the even. 
 15:24 And if any man lie with her at all, and her flowers be upon him, he shall be unclean seven days; and all the bed whereon he lieth shall be unclean. 
 15:25 And if a woman have an issue of her blood many days out of the time of her separation, or if it run beyond the time of her separation; all the days of the issue of her uncleanness shall be as the days of her separation: she shall be unclean. 
 15:26 Every bed whereon she lieth all the days of her issue shall be unto her as the bed of her separation: and whatsoever she sitteth upon shall be unclean, as the uncleanness of her separation.
 15:27 And whosoever toucheth those things shall be unclean, and shall wash his clothes, and bathe himself in water, and be unclean until the even. 
 15:28 But if she be cleansed of her issue, then she shall number to herself seven days, and after that she shall be clean. 
 15:29 And on the eighth day she shall take unto her two turtles, or two young pigeons, and bring them unto the priest, to the door of the tabernacle of the congregation. 
 15:30 And the priest shall offer the one for a sin offering, and the other for a burnt offering; and the priest shall make an atonement for her before the LORD for the issue of her uncleanness. 

 
 So essentially what we have here is the Bible saying that women must isolate herself for at least a week during her period, and sacrifice two turtles or pigeons after it. Any man who touches her (or her bed or even her chair!) is 'unclean' for a day, or if he goes so far as to sleep with her, unclean for a week. 
 
 Of course the Bible also cannot go for long without contradicting itself, and 20:18 decides that the punishment for a man having sex with a menstruating woman is to exile them both from society:
 
 
20:18 And if a man shall lie with a woman having her sickness, and shall uncover her nakedness; he hath discovered her fountain, and she hath uncovered the fountain of her blood: and both of them shall be cut off from among their people.

 
 This is just one of the many bizarre rules in the Bible that few Christians ever mention. But if it is the divine word of God then surely it is just as important to follow than anything on homosexuality?
